conclusion: Four homogeneous spheres of radius r and mass m each are stacked in a cone shape on a smooth horizontal surface.
Three balls (A, B, C) form a base on a horizontal surface, and ball D sits on top of the three balls.
The centers of A, B, and C are in the same horizontal plane.
The centers of balls A, B, and C form an equilateral triangle in a horizontal plane.
Ball D sits in the dimple formed by these three balls.
When identical spheres are stacked this way, their centers form a tetrahedron.
The distance between the centers of any two touching spheres is 2r.
The center of ball D is directly above the centroid of the equilateral triangle formed by the centers of A, B, and C.
The side length of the equilateral triangle formed by the centers of A, B, and C is s = 2r.
The distance from any vertex to the centroid of the equilateral triangle is h₁ = (2r)/√3.
Using the Pythagorean theorem, the height of ball D's center above the plane is h₂ = (2r)√(2/3).
The only forces acting on ball D are its weight (F_g = mg, downward) and the normal forces from each of the three lower balls (upward).
Due to symmetry, each of the lower balls exerts an equal normal force on ball D.
The normal force from each ball is along the line joining the centers of the balls.
The angle θ between the line joining the centers and the vertical is cos(θ) = h₂/2r = √(2/3).
Each normal force has a vertical component N_vertical = N·√(2/3).
For ball D to be in equilibrium, the sum of vertical forces must be zero: 3·N_vertical - mg = 0.
Solving for N gives N = mg·√(6)/6.
The pressure is the force per unit area, but in this context, it's better understood as the contact force.
The pressure (contact force) of ball D on each of the balls A, B, and C is P = N = mg·√(6)/6.
